Kolumna Dušana Malovrha: Samoprispevek samoplačnikov
Samoprispevek menda ponekod še izpeljejo, a je bolj plaha ptica, obročkana v socializmu.
06 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Dušan Malovrh
Roko na srce: Krisa Zudicha, fantka z najhujšo obliko bolezni spinalne mišične atrofije, v tako zvani socialni državi Sloveniji (2. člen ustave) rešuje zasebni sektor. Proti kalifornijski bolnišnici, poimenovani po nekdanjem ameriškem predsedniku Ronaldu Reaganu in v kateri so se zdravili tudi John Wayne, Marlon Brando in Michael Jackson, je malega Koprčana odpeljalo letalo srbskega bogataša. Seveda širokogrudni Miodrag Kostić ne bi mogel posoditi svojega reaktivca, če prej tudi stotisoči navadnih smrtnikov ne bi bili pripravljeni prispevati. Celo zadnjega evra, tako kot gospa Cvetka iz Kardoševe ulice v Murski Soboti.Denar so levjesrčku z Obale namenili tako Primorci kot Gorenjci, mladi in stari, levi in desni, socialisti in kapitalisti, ta rdeči in ta črni, narodnjaki in narodno-zabavni, tisti, ki se pišejo na -ić, -ič ali -ich. Za Krisa je stekla največja samoplačniška akcija v samostojni Sloveniji.V nekdanjem političnem sistemu v eks Jugi je bil utečen način pridobivanja sredstev za izredne projekte mimo proračunov in sistemov. Reklo se mu je samoprispevek. Česar ni zmogla ali hotela država, so morali ljudje. Tak način zbiranja denarja se je uveljavil v samoupravljanju, potem ko so minili udarniški časi izgradnje socializma. Samoprispevki so gradili vrtce, vodovode, ceste, tudi kakšno ambulanto, domnevam. Da bi morali s samoprispevki reševati življenje posamezniku, tega se pa ne spomnim. Sicer menda tudi še dandanes ponekod izpeljejo kakšnega, a zelo zelo redko, saj je samoprispevek bolj plaha ptica, obročkana v socializmu.Ob akciji za Krisa smo spoznali, kako krut bi bil turbokapitalizem brez solidarnosti. Država, ki očitno nikoli ne bo niti mala Švica, kaj šele velika Skandinavija, pa bi lahko svojim ljudem vseeno pomagala. Nekoč smo imeli na primer bencinski tolar za avtoceste, v bodoče bi lahko uvedli Krisov evro. Za žalostne zgodbe s srečnim koncem.In da ne pozabimo: v ZDA, kjer bodo za dva milijona zdravili slovenskega dečka, ogromno ljudi nima niti osnovnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja. Kako tam rešujejo svoje male Krise?

Dusan Malovrha's column: Self-contribution by self-payers
The self-contribution seems to be carried out in some places, but it is a more timid bird ringed in socialism.
06 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Dušan Malovrh
Hand on Heart: Kris Zudich, a boy with the most severe form of spinal muscular atrophy, in the so-called welfare state of Slovenia (Article 2 of the Constitution) is rescued by the private sector. The little Richman's plane was flown to a California hospital named after former President Ronald Reagan and treated by John Wayne, Marlon Brando and Michael Jackson. Of course, the generous Miodrag Kostic would not have been able to lend his reactor if hundreds of thousands of ordinary mortals had not been prepared to contribute before. Even the last euro, just like Mrs. Cvetka from Kardoševa Street in Murska Sobota. The money was given to the left-hearted people from the Coast by both Primorians and Gorenjci, young and old, left and right, socialists and capitalists, this red and this black, nationals and national-entertainment, those that spell -ich, -ich, or -ich. The largest self-paid campaign in independent Slovenia was launched for Kris. In the former political system in the former South, there was a well-established way of obtaining funds for extraordinary projects past budgets and systems. He was called a self-contributor. What the country couldn't do or wanted, people had to do. This way of raising money became established in self-government after the shocking times of building socialism had passed. The self-contributions were building kindergartens, water mains, roads, even an ambulance, I suppose. That self-contributions should save an individual's life, but I don't remember that. Otherwise, they seem to carry out some but still very rarely these days, since self-contribution is a more timid bird, ringed in socialism. We learned from the campaign for Chris how cruel turbo-capitalism would be without solidarity. A country that obviously will never be a small Switzerland, let alone a large Scandinavia, could still help its people. For example, we once had a motorway tolar, and in the future we could introduce the Kris Euro. To sad stories with a happy ending. And let's not forget: in the US, where two million people will be treated by a Slovenian boy, many people do not even have basic health insurance. How do they settle their little Chris in there?
